noun.description: A follower of the 14th century English religious reformerJohn Wycliffe. The Lollards believed that the church should aid people to live a life of evangelical poverty and imitate Jesus Christ. Their ideas influenced the thought of John Huss, who in turn influenced Martin Luther.

origin: Late Middle English: originally a derogatory term, derived from a Dutch word meaning mumbler, based on lollen to mumble.
